questions.text: Which of the following stages of meiosis has oogonia at the time of birth?
questions.solution:
Meiosis 1 of oogenesis begins in the embryonic period itself, but is arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I, which gets completed at the time of puberty. 

Note-

1. Oogonium- Derived from germ cell which undergoes mitosis to form primary oocyte. It is diploid.

2. Primary Oocyte- Halted in diplotene stage of prophase 1 until puberty. It is diploid.

3. Secondary Oocyte- Halted in metaphase II until fertilization. It is haploid.

4. Ovum- Haploid

questions.text: For which of the following muscles is a card test performed?

questions.text: At what stage of spermatocyte maturation does independent assortment of maternal and paternal chromosomes take place?
questions.solution:
When the primary spermatocyte (2n) transforms into two secondary spermatocytes (1n) during meiosis I in spermatogenesis, independent assortment takes place.

Meiosis I separates homologous chromosomes after crossing over ( which is responsible for exchange of genetic material ) and reduces the cell from diploid to haploid. 

Meiosis II separates the sister chromatids present in the chromosome which contain replicated DNA.

questions.text: In a study to assess extracellular fluid volume, 10 gm of mannitol was administered intravenously, and after allowing enough time for levels to equilibrate, concentration was determined to be 50 mg/100 ml. 10% of mannitol was eliminated over this period. What is the ECF's calculated volume?
questions.solution:
Since 10% was excreted therefore net amount in body was 10gm-(10*10/100)gm=10-1=9gm

Now if X liters is the volume of ECF then,9/X=50mg/100ml
                                                                  9/X=½
                                                                  X=9*2=18 litres

questions.text: If the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 25 mm Hg and the interstitial hydrostatic pressure is 2 mm Hg, respectively, then the interstitial oncotic pressure is 7 mm Hg. What capillary oncotic pressure must exist for a 3 mm Hg net filtration pressure to be possible?
questions.solution:
By, Starling's equation
Filtration Pressure = Kf[(Pgc - Pt) - (pgc - pbs)]

3=(25-2)-(pgc-7)
3=23-pgc+7
Therefore, pgc=27
Where
Kf = glomerular filtration coefficient (product of glomerular surface times hydraulic conductivity)
Pgc = capillary hydrostatic pressure
Pbs = interstitial hydrostatic pressure
pgc = capillary oncotic pressure
pbs = interstitial oncotic pressure


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.text: What region on the body doesn't have brown adipose tissues?

questions.text: Which are the adrenergic beta-receptors that have the ability to cause lipolysis in fat cells?
questions.solution:
The adrenergic receptor that primarily mediates lipolysis (breakdown of fat) in fat cells is the beta-3 adrenergic receptor .Activation of β3 receptors leads to an increase in the intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), which in turn activates hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for catalyzing the breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, which are released into the bloodstream.

Other adrenergic receptors, such as the alpha-1 and beta-1 receptors, do not significantly contribute to lipolysis in fat cells. Therefore, β3 adrenergic receptors are specifically targeted in therapeutic approaches aimed at promoting fat breakdown in adipose tissue.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 256

questions.text: What happens to blood flow if the blood vessel's radius is expanded by 50%?
questions.solution:
Blood flow through a vessel follows Poiseuille's law, which states that blood flow (Q) is directly proportional to the fourth power of the vessel's radius (r ‚Å¥):
Q∝r4

If initial radius is R, and now radius is increased by 50%, the new radius is 1.5R. 
Hence blood flow will increase by (1.5)^4 = 1.5 X 1.5 X 1.5 X1.5 = 5.06X ~ 5X.  Thus, blood flow increases approximately 5 times.

The correct answer is 5 times. 

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26th Page no 563

questions.text: Lactic acidosis in thiamine shortage is caused by which of the following enzyme dysfunctions?
questions.solution:
Since thiamine pyrophosphate is a cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase, which catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl Co-A, thiamine shortage prevents pyruvate from being converted to acetyl Co-A. Therefore, lactate dehydrogenase converts extra pyruvate to lactate. This is responsible for lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was diagnosed with an abdominal mass. The para-aortic lymph nodes appear significantly enlarged on imaging. A starry sky pattern was noted during the biopsy. What is the underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Translocation involving Myc gene
 
  • A biopsy finding of a starry eye pattern strongly suggests Burkitt lymphoma. The c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 is linked with all forms of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • Burkitt's lymphoma has a very high mitotic index resulting in generation of many apoptotic and necrotic cells due to outgrowing of their blood supply.
  • The nuclear remnants of these cells are phagocytosed by the macrophages.
  • These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm resembling the stars while the small round blue tumor cells represent the sky, giving rise to starry sky pattern. 
  • Most common presentation of endemic Burkitt's is a mass involving the mandible whereas sporadic burkitt's appears as a mass involving peritoneum and ileocecum. 
  • Other options - p53 mutation - Li fraumeni syndrome, Rb - Retinoblastoma, BCR - ABL - CML
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 601.

questions.text: Following an incised wound, one can observe fresh collagen fibrils and a thick layer of developing epithelium. The age of the wound is about:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) About 1 week

As there is mention of fresh collagen fibrils correct timeline would be about 1 week
As per the options, Granulation tissue appears on Day 3, but Thick layers of Developing epithelium comes in about 1 wk. so Answer should be Option 2> Option 1.
* Timeline Of Wound Healing by Primary Intention:
 
  • Within 24 hours, neutrophils are seen at the incision margin, migrating toward the fibrin clot.
  • Within 24 to 48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges have begun to migrate and proliferate along the dermis yielding a thin but continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound.
  • By day 3, neutrophils have been largely replaced by macrophages, and granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space. The macrophages clear extracellular debris, fibrin, and other foreign material and promote angiogenesis and ECM deposition.
  • By day 5, neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space. Thus, new granulation tissue is often edematous. Fibroblasts progressively migrate into the granulation tissue, where they proliferate and lay down collagen and ECM.
  • During the second week, there is continued collagen accumulation and fibroblast proliferation.
  • By the end of the first month, the scar comprises a cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells and covered by an essentially normal epidermis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 109.

choices.text: Hypersensitivity reaction with modified macrophages, lymphocytes and giant cells

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with fever, night sweats, and weight loss. On X-ray, a mass was seen in the apical lobe. On histopathology, caseous necrosis was present. What is the underlying process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Hypersensitivity reaction with modified macrophages, lymphocytes and giant cells
 
  • Clinical signs of fever, night sweats, weight loss along with X-ray finding of a mass in the apical lobe and histopathological evidence of caseous necrosis is suggestive of tuberculosis. 
  • The underlying pathophysiology involves Type IV hypersensitivity reaction which is characterized by the presence of giant cells, epithelioid cells and modified macrophage lymphocytes.
  • Immune Mechanisms: Activated T lymphocytes → (1) release of cytokines, inflammation and macrophage activation (2) T cell–mediated cytotoxicity
  • Histopathological markers: Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 204.

Gynecomastia may be present. (Hence - option 4 is correct)

questions.text: What is the purpose of CYP enzymes' xenobiotic metabolism?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option (1) Increase in water solubility > Option (3) conversion to active metabolite. 

The primary purpose of cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzymes in xenobiotic metabolism is increase in water solubility
CYP enzymes primarily function in Phase I metabolism, introducing functional groups (such as hydroxylation) to increase a compound’s water solubility. This modification facilitates further metabolism (such as conjugation in Phase II) and renal or biliary excretion.

Other Options:
Option (2) Increase in lipid solubility – CYP enzymes generally make compounds more polar, reducing lipid solubility. Hence option (2) is incorrect.

Option (3) Some CYP enzymes do convert prodrugs into active metabolites (such as codeine to morphine via CYP2D6), but this is not their primary function. (which is why option 1 is the best answer)

Option (4) Xenobiotic metabolism aims for excretion via urine or bile, not evaporation through the skin.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 557.

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rosiglitazone

Rosiglitazone does not act by increasing insulin secretion. Rosiglitazone is an oral antihyperglycemic agent that acts primarily by decreasing insulin resistance.

* Mechanism of action:
  • Potent and highly selective agonist for peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARg). 
  • PPAR receptors are found in tissues important for insulin action such as adipose tissue, skeletal muscle and liver (highest level in adipose tissue).
  • Activation of (PPAR) nuclear receptors modulates the transcription of a number of insulin responsive genes involved in the control of glucose & lipid metabolism. 
  • Rosiglitazone appears to reduce insulin resistance by enhancing fatty acids storage and possibly by increasing adiponectin levels

* Other options: 
2. Repaglinide- Is a meglitinide which increases insulin release
3. Exenatide- GLP 1 analogue which increases insulin release
4. Sitagliptin- It is a DPP-4 inhibitor, it increases incretin level, which in turn increases insulin release

Anti Diabetic Drugs -
 
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
1. Insulin - Regular insulin- Long-acting (e.g., glargine)- Rapid-acting (e.g., lispro) Mimics natural insulin to control blood glucose.
2. Insulin Secretagogues DPP-4 Inhibitors: sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin
GLP-1 Agonists: exenatide, liraglutide-
Sulfonylureas: glibenclamide, glimepiride
 Meglitinides: repaglinide, nateglinide		 Stimulate insulin release from the pancreas.
3. Drugs that Reduce Insulin Resistance - Biguanides: metformin-
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs): pioglitazone, rosiglitazone		 Improve insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat.
4. SGLT-2 Inhibitors - Empagliflozin- Canagliflozin Increase glucose excretion by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption.
5. Alpha-glucosidase Inhibitors - Acarbose- Miglitol Slow carbohydrate breakdown, reducing post-meal blood sugar spikes.
6. Amylin Analogs - Pramlintide Delay gastric emptying and reduce glucagon release.
7. Bile Acid Sequestrants - Colesevelam Improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not cause amorphous whorls like corneal deposits?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Chlorthiazide
 
  • A case of vortex keratopathy is suggested by an amorphous whorl-like corneal deposit. All of the aforementioned drugs, except chlorthiazide cause this syndrome.
  • Deposits in the inferior and central cornea in a whorl-like pattern termed cornea verticillata. Appears as fine tan or brown pigment in the epithelium. Deposits seldom affect vision
  • This is a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium seen in patients on long-term treatment with medication such as Amiodarone, Chloroquine, Phenothiazines and Indomethacin. It is also seen in patients with Fabry disease and its carrier state.
  • The condition is generally asymptomatic, harmless and reversible on stopping the drug. The whorl-like pattern shows the direction of migration of corneal epithelial cells. Occasionally, the condition has been known to cause glare and surface discomfort which responds to topical lubricants.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 193.

questions.text: What is the most effective antihypertensive medication for pulmonary hypertension

3. Amlodipine- It is a Calcium Channel Blocker used in hypertension

The treatment of PAH is important for INICET -

First we will do a Vasoreactivity test, if it is positive the DOC is Ca Channel blockers. If negative based on severity we can use oral drugs like PDE inhibitors like Sildenafil or Endothelin Receptor antagonists like Bosentan. Severe cases we can use IV Prostaglandins, inhaled NO etc.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thiazide diuretic

Thiazide diuretic can be given in mild to moderate hypertension.
  • Low-dose thiazide diuretics may be used alone or in combination with other antihypertensive drugs.
  • Thiazides inhibit the Na+Cl- pump in the distal convoluted tubule and hence increase sodium excretion. In the long term, they also may act as vasodilators.
  • Thiazides are safe, efficacious, inexpensive, and reduce clinical events.
  • They provide additive blood pressure-lowering effects when combined with beta blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE/s), or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

  • Its action is more prolonged because the added methyl group increases its resistance to hydrolysis by cholinesterases.

questions.text: What kind of acetylcholinesterase inhibition does organophosphates cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Competitive & Irreversible.

Organophosphates which are tertiary Amino compounds react covalently with the esteretic site of the enzyme Acetylcholinesterase which leads to irreversible and competitive inhibition of the enzyme.

A Competitive non-equilibrium type of enzyme inhibition occurs with drugs which react with the same catalytic site of the enzyme but either form strong covalent bonds or have such high affinity for the enzyme that the normal substrate is not able to displace the inhibitor.
Another example of the same type of enzyme inhibition is 50,000 times higher affinity of Methotrexate for dihydrofolate reductase than the normal substrate DHFA.


In these situations, kM is increased and Vmax is reduced contrary to unchanged Vmax in Competitive equilibrium type of enzyme inhibition.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: What causes tropical spastic paresis?
questions.solution:
TSP is known as HTLV-1 associated myelopathy which leads to inflammation of spinal cord.

HTLV-1 is a retrovirus that primarily affects T-cells and can lead to a chronic neurological condition, which manifests as tropical spastic paresis, characterized by spasticity, weakness, and sensory disturbances, particularly in the lower limbs.

 

Other options:

• HIV (option 1): While HIV can cause neurological complications, it does not typically cause tropical spastic paresis. However, HIV-associated myelopathy or HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders can occur in some cases.

• HBV (option 2): Hepatitis B virus (HBV) primarily affects the liver and does not cause tropical spastic paresis.

• EBV (option 4): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with infectious mononucleosis and other conditions like certain cancers, but not with tropical spastic paresis.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 571.

questions.text: Where is the IgE receptor found?
questions.solution:
The IgE receptor (FcεRI) is primarily found on: Mast cells/Basophils and Eosinophils (to a lesser extent)

This receptor binds IgE antibodies, playing a crucial role in allergic reactions and parasite defense. When an allergen cross-links IgE bound to mast cells, it triggers degranulation, releasing histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

Other options

  • Promonocyte (2): These are precursors to monocytes/macrophages and do not express FcεRI.

  • T lymphocyte (3): T cells do not have FcεRI; they interact with antigens via T-cell receptors (TCR).

  • NK cell (4): Natural Killer (NK) cells express Fcγ receptors (for IgG) but not FcεRI.


  

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

choices.text: Doctor is guilty under “Last clear chance” doctrine
Doctor is guilty as he prescribed wrong medicines

questions.text: An orthopaedic surgeon urged a patient to get his wound dressed on a daily basis. However, the patient was unconcerned. During follow-up, the patient was frequently told to get the dressing done on time, but the patient refused, claiming that he was too busy. Finally, the wound grew larger, and the underlying bone became infected with osteomyelitis.
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the correct answer.

The concept of "contributory negligence" applies when the plaintiff's own negligence contributes to their injury or damages. In this case, the patient's failure to follow the doctor's advice and get the dressing done on time resulted in the worsening of the wound and later development of osteomyelitis. Therefore, the patient should be considered to have contributed to their own injury.


Other options

Option 1
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄãThe "last clear chance" doctrine is a legal principle that applies to cases of contributory negligence, where both the plaintiff and defendant were negligent, but the defendant had the last clear chance to avoid harm. However, in this situation, the doctor did not have the last clear chance to prevent harm, as the patient had the opportunity to take care of the wound by getting the dressing done on time.

Option 3
Negligence is the failure to take reasonable care that a prudent person would take in similar circumstances. If the doctor failed to provide adequate instructions or follow-up care, or if the doctor prescribed the wrong medicines, then they may be held liable for avoidable negligence. However, based on the information provided in the question, there is no evidence that the doctor committed avoidable negligence.

Option 4
The question does not provide any information to suggest that the doctor prescribed the wrong medicines. Therefore, it is incorrect to state that the doctor is guilty of prescribing wrong medicines.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: Following a collision, two bodies are discovered outside the vehicle. The doctor performing the autopsy would be able to differentiate and determine who was the driver and who was passenger based on all the below parameters EXCEPT _________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Sparrow footmarks.
 
  • Sparrow footmarks occur in both driver as well as passenger. It does not differentiate between driver and passenger.
  • Steering wheel imprint (option 2) and seat belt abrasion over right shoulder (option 4) will occur primarily in the driver. Hence, presence of steering wheel impact and abrasion over right shoulder would help in identification of driver.
  • Whiplash injury (option 1) can occur in both front seat occupant and driver but is more common in front seat occupant because the driver stabilizes his neck just before impact (due to early perception of impact) - hence even whiplash injury can help in differentiation. 
  • When injury occurs, the glass broke and shatters into small cubes. These glass cubes may cause “V” shaped lacerations. These are called as dicing injuries or sparrow-foot lacerations. They would present equally in both driver and passenger and hence we would not be able to differentiate based on them.

questions.text: The average GFR in a group of 100 participants is 85 ml/min, with a standard deviation of 25. What is the 90% confidence interval range?
questions.solution:
Range or 90% confidence interval in the given question is 81-89.

Confidence Intervals
The Lower Limit and Upper Limit estimates for the Statistic are given as:
Lower Limit: statistic - C x SE (statistic)
Upper Limit: statistic+ C x SE (statistic)
.Standard Error, SE= {Standard Deviation / n1/2}      where, n = sample size


Confidence coefficient:

C = Confidence coefficient = 1.65 for 90% confidence interval 
                                            = 1.96 for 95% confidence interval ,its approx 2
                                            = 2.58 for 99% confidence interval, its approx 3

In this question:
n1/2= 10; SD = 25
SE= 25/ 10 = 2.5
Lower limit= 85- (1.65 x 2.5) = 85 - 4 = 81
Upper limit= 85+ (1.65 x 2.5) = 85 + 4 = 89

Hence, 90% CI will be 81-89.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 19.

questions.text: A researcher wishes to conduct a study of lipid levels in the blood of smokers and non-smokers. However, he is now concerned that smokers may differ from non-smokers in their diet, activity, and so on. This is referred to as:
questions.solution:
The researcher is concerned that the smokers in the query may have different dietary, exercise, and other habits from non-smokers. Selection bias is the name for this issue.
  • Bias is any systematic error in the determination of the association between the exposure and disease. The relative risk estimate may increase or decrease as a result of the bias; it reflects some type of non-comparability between the study and control groups. The possibility of bias must be considered when evaluating a possible cause and effect relationship.
  • Many varieties of bias may arise in epidemiological studies.
  • Some of these are :
(a) Bias due to confounding : Mention has already been made about confounding as an important source of bias. This bias can be removed by matching in case control studies.
(b) Memory or recall bias : When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.
(c) Selection bias : The cases and controls may not be representative of cases and controls in the general population. There may be systematic differences in characteristics between cases and controls. The selection bias can be best controlled by its prevention
(d) Berkesonian bias : A special example of bias is Berkesonian bias, termed after Dr. Joseph Berkeson who recognized this problem. The bias arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases (i.e., hospital cases and controls). 
(e) Interviewer’s bias : Bias may also occur when the interviewer knows the cases from the controls. This prior information may lead him to question the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding a positive history of the suspected causal factor. A useful check on this kind of bias can be made by providing equal time to interview both the case and control or by giving a self administered questionnaire to the cases and control. This type of bias can be eliminated by double-blinding .

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 82.

questions.text: The blood pressures of 200 people were measured. The data's first quartile BP was 94 mm Hg, while the third quartile was 110 mm Hg. How many patients have blood pressures that fall between the third and fourth quartiles?
questions.solution:
In the given question, fifty patients have blood pressures between the 3rd and 4th quartile.

Quartile:
In descriptive statistics, the quartiles of a ranked set of data values are the three points that divide the data set into four equal groups, each group comprising a quarter of the data.

A quartile is a type of quantile.

The first quartile (Q1) is defined as the middle number between the smallest number and the median of the data set.
The second quartile (Q2) is the median of the data.
The Third quartile (Q3) is the middle value between the median and the highest value of the data set.

First quartile (designated QI) also called the lower quartile or the 25th percentile (splits off the lowest 25% of data from the highest 75%).
Second quartile (designated Q2) also called median or the 50"' percentile (cuts data set in half).
Third quartile (designated Q3) also called the upper quartile or the 75"' percentile (splits off the highest 25% of data from the lowest 75%).

Interquartile range (designated IQR) is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles. (IQR= Q3- QI)

In the given question, between every two quartiles one/ fourth of the total number of patients are present, i.e.
200/4 = 50 patients.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

choices.text: Entry of pathogen to appearance of first clinical symptoms
Entry in cell to expulsion of first viral particle

questions.text: The window period is defined as the time elapsed between
questions.solution:
Window period:
  • Time between first infection & when the test can reliably detect that infection.
  • In antibody-based testing, the window period is dependent on the time taken for sero- conversion.

Incubation period:
  • Time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease in question.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 107.

questions.text: Tuberculin testing is a low-cost and widely available test. Which of the following scenarios has a high failure rate in test interpretation?
questions.solution:
When there is a high percentage of immunized people in the population due to a high BCG coverage rate, there is a significant failure rate in the interpretation of the tuberculin test.

The tuberculin test has lost its sensitivity as a gauge of the true prevalence of infection in nations with high BCG coverage, which also results in tuberculin hypersensitivity.

Atypical mycobacteria infection and the "boosting effect" of a second dosage of tuberculin eliciting a stronger reaction than the first could both overstate the genuine prevalence rates of infection.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 216.

questions.text: When compared to prior years, the number of non-communicable disease cases has gradually increased. What do you name this trend?
questions.solution:
The term 'secular trend ' implies changes in the occurrence of disease over a long period of time, generally several years
or decades. There may be progressive increase or decrease in the occurrence of disease.
Examples includes
  • coronary heart disease,
  • lung cancer and
  • diabetes
which have shown a consistent upward trend in the developed countries during the past 50 years or so, followed by a decline of such diseases as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria and polio.

Epidemiologists have identified three kinds of time trends or fluctuations in disease occurrence.

1. Short-term fluctuations. Eg epidemics
Il. Periodic fluctuations. Eg seasonal outbreaks
Ill. Long-term or secular trends

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 74.

questions.text: What does sensitivity measure?
questions.solution:
Sensitivity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is “true-positive” out of the total diseased(true-positive +false negative).
A 90 per cent sensitivity means that 90 per cent of the diseased people screened by the test will give a “true-positive” result and the remaining 10 per cent a “false-negative” result.
 
Diseased (TD) Healthy (TH)
Test Positive True positive (Tp) False Positive (Fp) PPV\(=\frac{\text{(TP)}}{\text{(TP)+(FP)}}\)
Test Negative False Negative (FN) True negative (TN) NPV\(=\frac{\text{(TN)}}{\text{(FN)+(TN)}}\)
Sensitivity\(=\frac{\text{(TP)}}{\text{(TP)+(FN)}}\) Specificity\(=\frac{\text{(TN)}}{\text{(FP)+(TN)}}\)


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 155.

questions.text: A man arrives with aphasia. He is unable to name items, and his repetition is poor. However, comprehension, fluency, and understanding of written language are unchanged. He's presumably suffering from?
questions.solution:
• Conduction aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus.
  • The connection between the Wernicke's (language comprehension) and Broca's (Language production) areas is lost.
  • The hallmark of conduction aphasia is the inability to repeat words. Comprehension and the expression of language are intact but patients cannot transfer the understood word to Broca's area to be expressed.
  • Conduction aphasia results in meaningful fluent speech and relatively good comprehension but very poor repetition.



Reference : HARRISON'S Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition - pg.196 table 30.1

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Duke's Criteria for Infectious Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Splenomegaly
 
Splenomegaly is not included in Duke's Criteria for Infectious Endocarditis.

* [Extra Edge]: Modified Duke Criteria



• Definitive diagnosis: Two major criteria or one major and three minor criteria or five minor criteria.
• Possible diagnosis: One major and one minor criterion or three minor criteria.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 564.

choices.text: Send blood for tests, start IV glucose and send to CT
Start normal saline and send to CT
Airway, CT scan, Blood sugar if <70 start dextrose

questions.text:
A middle-aged man arrives with bleeding from the scalp following a car accident. He is not awake.
A card in his pocket states that he is a diabetic who takes Tab Glimepiride + Metformin 2 tablets twice a day. What should the next move be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Airway, CT scan, Blood Sugar if <70 start dextrose
 
  • First testing of blood sugar is necessary before giving glucose as the patient may also be dehydrated and be in diabetic ketoacidotic coma rather then hypoglycemia.
  • A NCCT head is advisable in emergency situations as administration of glucose can lead to cerebral edema. Airway should be secured as well.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 541.

questions.text: A young lady presents with signs of uncontrollable movements. Acute rheumatic fever and Sydenham's chorea are suspected. Other key Rheumatic fever criteria (arthritis, skin rashes, subcutaneous nodules, and carditis) were not present. There was no sign of a sore throat. What is the best inquiry to prove rheumatic aetiology?
questions.solution:
In the scenario described, where a young lady presents with signs of uncontrollable movements suggestive of Sydenham's chorea and acute rheumatic fever, but without other common criteria (like arthritis, skin rashes, subcutaneous nodules, or carditis), and no signs of a sore throat, the best inquiry to prove a rheumatic etiology would be:

2. Antistreptolysin O (ASO)

The ASO titer measures antibodies against streptolysin O, a substance produced by group A Streptococcus. An elevated ASO titer can indicate a recent streptococcal infection, which is relevant for diagnosing rheumatic fever.

While throat culture (option 3) could help identify an active infection, it may not be applicable in the absence of a sore throat.
PCR for M protein (option 4) could detect the bacteria but is less commonly used for diagnosing rheumatic fever compared to ASO.

Therefore, Antistreptolysin O (ASO) is the best choice for proving the rheumatic etiology in this case.

 
World Health Criteria for the diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever and Rheumatic Heart Disease
Major Criteria Minor Criteria Supporting evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection within the last 45 days
  1. Carditis
  2. Migratory polyarthritis
  3. Syndenham's chorea
  4. Subcutaneousnodules0
  5. Erythema marginatum
  • Clinical: Fever, polyarthralgia
  • Laboratory: Elevated ESR or leukocyte count
  • ECG: Prolonged P-R interval
 Revised Jones criteria do
not include elevated leucocyte count as a  laboratory minor mani- festation (but do include elevated C-reactive protein)
  • Elevated or rising anti-streptolysin O or other streptococcal antibody, or
  • A positive throat culture, or
  • Rapid antigen test for group A streptococcus0, or
  • Recent scarlet fever @1992 Revised Jones
criteria do not include recent scarlet fever as
supporting evidence of a recent streptococcal infection



 
Diagnostic categories Criteria
Primary episode of rheumatic fever Two major or one major two minor manifestations plus evidence of preceding group A streptococcal infection
Recurrent attack of rheumatic fever in a patient without established rheumatic heart disease Two major or one minor manifestations plus evidence of
preceding group A streptococcal infection
Recurrent attack of rheumatic fever in a patient with established rheumatic heart disease Two minor manifestations plus evidence of preceding group A streptococcal infection


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 218.

questions.text: What course of action should be taken if a person tests negative for anti-HBc Ab but positive for HBsAg?
questions.solution:
This is a case of chronic Hepatitis B because the patient has HBsAg but no Anti-HBc Ab. Before starting treatment, an HBV-DNA load should be performed. In general, for both HBeAg-reactive and HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B, the quantity of HBV DNA corresponds with the severity of liver damage and risk of progression. Chronic HBV infection can occur in the presence or absence of serum hepatitis B antigen (HBeAg).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 552.

choices.text: Risk factors include sepsis and cardiac surgeries
It’s a cause of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema
Plasma is more likely to cause it than whole blood

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about transfusion-related acute lung injury?
questions.solution:
Develops after 24 hours is thee incorrect statement.
 
  • TRALI typically develops within 6 hours of BT. In rare cases, it may develop upto 72 hours.
  • TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.
  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability.
  • Clinical Features: The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia (PaO2/FiO2 <300 mmHg) and signs of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. 
  • Diagnosis: Testing the donor's plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can support this diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 891, 894.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an autoimmune disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ulcerative colitis

The most appropriate option after elimination is ulcerative collitis rest all have autoimmune etiology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 799.

choices.text: Pregnant woman with sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B
People on long-term steroids cannot receive Oseltamivir
Category B concerns with low risk cases
Category B patients have to undergo immediate testing

questions.text: Which of the following statements about H1N1 influenza is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pregnant woman with sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B

Regarding H1N1 Influenza, a pregnant woman with a sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B.

* Category A Patient Of H1N1 Influenza:
Patients with mild fever (less than 380 C) plus cough / sore throat with or without bodyache, headache, diarrhoea and vomitting will be categorized as Category-A. They do not require Oseltamivir and should be treated for the symptoms mentioned above. The patients should be monitored for their progress and reassessed at 24 to 48 hours by the doctor.

* Category B Patient of H1N1 Influenza:
In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, if the patient has high grade fever (Above 380 C) and severe sore throat, may require home isolation and Oseltamivir.
In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, individuals having one or more of the following high-risk conditions shall be treated with Oseltamivir:
ÔÇ∑ Children with mild illness but with predisposing risk factors.
ÔÇ∑ Pregnant women;
ÔÇ∑ Persons aged 65 years or older;
ÔÇ∑ Patients with lung diseases, heart disease, liver disease, Kidney disease, blood disorders, diabetes, neurological disorders, cancer and HIV/AIDS;
Patients on long term cortisone therapy.
ÔÇ∑ No test for Influenza is required for Category-B (i) and (ii).
ÔÇ∑ All patients of Category-B (i) and (ii) should confine themselves at home and avoid mixing with public and high risk members in the family.
ÔÇ∑ Broad Spectrum antibiotics as per the Guideline for Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) may be prescribed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 853.
Online Reference: Guidelines on categorization of Influenza A H1N1 cases during screening for home isolation, testing treatment, and hospitalization (Revised on 05.10.09) https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/224678457.pdf

questions.text: Which one of the following does not exhibit hyperdynamic circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cor pulmonale
 
  • Hyperdynamic circulation is seen in anemia, beriberi & AV fistula, but not in Cor pulmonale.
  • Cor pulmonale has a depressed ejection fraction (<40%). 
* [Extra Edge]: 
  • In acute cor pulmonale there is marked dilation of the right ventricle without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle chamber is transformed to a dilated ovoid.
  • In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens, sometimes up to 1.0 cm or more. More subtle right ventricular hypertrophy may take the form of thickening of the muscle bundles in the outflow tract, immediately below the pulmonary valve, or thickening of the moderator band, the muscle bundle that connects the ventricular septum to the anterior right ventricular papillary muscle. Sometimes, the hypertrophied right ventricle compresses the left ventricular chamber or leads to regurgitation and fibrous thickening of the tricuspid valve.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 556.

questions.text: Which of the following does not usually cause a reduction in the diffusion lung capacity of carbon monoxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asthma
 
  • During an episode of acute asthma, luminal narrowing due to smooth muscle constriction, inflammation, and thickening within the small- and medium-sized bronchi raise frictional resistance and reduce airflow. "Scooping" of the flow-volume loop is caused by a reduction of airflow, especially at lower lung volumes. 
  • DLCO decreases in diseases that i) thicken or destroy alveolar membranes (e.g. pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema); ii) curtail the pulmonary vasculature (e.g. pulmonary hypertension) or reduce alveolar capillary hemoglobin (eg. anemia). 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 684.

questions.text: Where is hypertensive haemorrhage most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
• Hypertensive ICH usually results from spontaneous rupture of a small penetrating artery deep in the brain.
  • The most common sites are the basal ganglia (especially the putamen), thalamus, cerebellum, and pons.
  • The small arteries in these areas seem most prone to hypertension-induced vascular injury.
 
  • ICH accounts for ~10% of all strokes, and ~35–45% of patients die within the first month. Incidence rates are particularly high in Asians and blacks.
  • Hypertension, coagulopathy, sympathomimetic drugs (cocaine, methamphetamine), and cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) cause most of these hemorrhages.



Transaxial NCCT Brain showing Hypertensive basal ganglia hemorrhage



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3349.

choices.text: Establish IV line and start normal saline
Needle decompression on right side of the chest

questions.text: A pregnant woman who was stabbed in the right side of the chest was seen screaming and yelling as she entered the casualty area. The patient is tachycardic and has a blood pressure reading of 90/60 mm Hg. On her right side, her breath noises are less audible. What will be the first line of action
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Needle decompression on right side of the chest.
 
  • This case is a classical description of tension pneumothorax of the right hemithorax with decreased breath sounds.
  • Since the patient is shouting, it means her airway is clear.
  • Current teaching advocates undertaking decompression in safe triangle.
(Bailey & Love 28th edition) followed by the insertion of an IV line and fluid administration.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 374.

questions.text: From where does the bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear usually occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Left gastric artery
 
  • Mallory-Weiss tears are related to forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining.
  • Most Mallory-Weiss tears stop bleeding spontaneously and supportive treatment is all that is required. If bleeding continues, infusion of vasoactive substances into the celiac artery into the left gastric artery often obviates the need for operation.
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome is characterized by longitudinal mucosal lacerations (intramural dissection) in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach, which are usually associated with forceful or prolonged vomiting or retching. The lacerations often lead to bleeding from submucosal arterial plexus.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1167.

questions.text: What factor best determines the prognosis of esophageal cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) T stage
 
  • Long-term survival following esophagectomy depends on a number of factors such as the number of involved lymph nodes (N), depth of the tumor invasion (T), and the location of the tumor in the esophagus.
  • In esophageal cancer, the prognosis is best determined by the T stage, among the options provided.
* Prognosis is better for tumors of the cervical esophagus and tumors located at the GE junction. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 762.

questions.text: In a patient with multiple clotting factor deficiency and active bleeding, the following blood product is recommended:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fresh frozen plasma
 
  • The best blood product to be given to a patient with multiple clotting factor deficiency with active bleeding is fresh frozen plasma.
  • Fresh frozen plasma is also indicated for a planned surgery or invasive procedure in the presence of abnormal coagulation tests, the reversal of warfarin in the presence of active bleeding, or a planned procedure when vitamin K is inadequate to reverse the warfarin effect, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and congenital or acquired factor deficiency with no alternative therapy.
  • Fresh frozen plasma contains all coagulation factors except platelets.
  • Fresh frozen plasma contains fibrinogen (400 to 900 mg/unit), albumin, protein C, protein S, antithrombin, and tissue factor pathway inhibitors. It is free of erythrocytes and leukocytes. 
  • Fresh frozen plasma corrects coagulopathy by replacing or supplying plasma proteins in patients deficient in or defective plasma proteins.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2630.
Online Reference: Khawar H, Kelley W, Stevens JB, et al. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) [Updated 2022 Sep 19]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513347/

choices.text: Start antithyroid drugs, and do urgent MRI brain
Start antithyroid drugs and wait for symptoms to resolve

questions.text: A young woman had high FT4 and TSH level of 8.5 IU/l and hyperthyroidism symptoms. Bitemporal hemianopia is discovered upon closer inspection. What will be the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Start antithyroid drugs, and do an urgent MRI brain.
 
  • Bitemporal hemianopia with hyperthyroidism (elevated TSH and T4) is highly suggestive of Central hyperthyroidism due to TSH-secreting adenoma. MRI should be done to confirm the diagnosis of pituitary adenoma. 
 
  • Patients usually present with thyroid goiter and hyperthyroidism, reflecting chronic overproduction of TSH.
  • Diagnosis is based on demonstrating elevated serum free T4 levels, inappropriately normal or high TSH secretion, and MRI evidence of a pituitary adenoma.
  • Elevated free glycoprotein hormone α subunits are seen in many patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2917, 2918.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer in her family arrives with blood-stained discharge from her nipple. What would be the ideal next move for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sono mammogram
 
  • The ideal next step would be to perform a Sono mammogram (Ultrasound Mammography). This imaging technique is useful for evaluating breast tissue and identifying potential underlying causes of the discharge, such as ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive breast cancer.
  • There is current interest in the use of MRI to screen the breasts of high-risk women and of women with newly diagnosed breast cancer.
  • Women who have a strong family history of breast cancer or who carry known genetic mutations require screening at an early age, but the mammographic evaluation is limited because of the increased breast density in younger women.

Fig: Bloody Nipple Discharge

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 929.

questions.text:
A woman who is 9 weeks pregnant presents with a 2.5 cm lump in the left breast's upper outer quadrant. The ultrasound did not detect any abnormality.
What will be the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Finger guided core biopsy

Most breast lesions in pregnancy are benign but a biopsy should be done to rule out malignancy. Core-needle biopsy with or without ultrasound guidance is a safe and reliable method for obtaining tissue.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: Which patients with breast cancer undergo an oncotype DX test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chemotherapy in hormone receptor positive patients

Oncotype Dx may be used to guide chemotherapy decisions among certain women with :

i)  Node negative
ii) Hormone receptor-positive 
iii) Her 2 negative breast cancer

Oncotype Dx® is the most widely used ROR score and measures the expression of 16 cancer-related genes and fve reference genes on paraffin-embedded tumour tissue. The assay classifies the ROR score as low (<18), moderate (19–30) or high (>30). In patients with a low ROR score, chemotherapy can be avoided.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 940.

questions.text: A 3 year old child is diagnosed to have hernia with hydrocele. What is the line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Management of hydrocele of the hernia sac (congenital hydrocele) in a 3 years old child is herniotomy.
 
  • A patent processus vaginalis may allow only peritoneal fluid to track down around the testis to form a hydrocoele.
  • Hydrocele are unilateral or bilateral, asymptomatic, tender scrotal swellings.
  • They may be tense or lax, but typically transilluminate.
  • The majority resolve spontaneously as the processus continues to obliterate, but surgical ligation is recommended in boys older than three years of age.

Fig: Hydrocele

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 256.

questions.text: What is the most frequently used shunt for hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Therapy for hydrocephalus depends on the cause.
  • Medical management, including the use of acetazolamide and furosemide, can provide temporary relief by reducing the rate of CSF production, but long-term results have been disappointing.
  • Most cases of hydrocephalus require extracranial shunts, particularly a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.
  • Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) has evolved as a viable approach and criteria have been developed for its use, but the procedure might need to be repeated to be effective.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 578
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3080

questions.text: Unintentionally, a staple was positioned below and lateral to the iliopubic tract during laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. The patient reported thigh pain and soreness following the surgery. Which nerve is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of inadvertent placement of surgical stapler in the triangle of pain during laparoscopic mesh repair of inguinal hernia involving lateral cutaneous of thigh causing thigh pain.
 

Fig: Mesh fixation with tacks. 1. above the pubic bone; 2. medial to epigastric vessels; 3. lateral to inferior epigastric vessels, 4. Two centimeters above iliopubic tract

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1074.

questions.text: A splenectomy was performed on a female with steroid-resistant ITP. On day 3 post-laparoscopy surgery, the patient had a fever. Which are the most likely scenarios to follow?
questions.solution:
Fever on postoperative day 3 after laparoscopic splenectomy suggests left lower lobe consolidation.
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after OS; pleural effusion and pneumonia also can occur.

Hemorrhage can occur intraoperatively or postoperatively, presenting as subphrenic hematoma. Subphrenic abscess and wound infection are among the perioperative infectious complications.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 381.

questions.text: Which incision is the most effective for diaphragmatic surgery?
questions.solution:
Circumferential incisions in diaphragm are the safest incisions as they result in little loss of function. These circumferential incisions, however, must be at least 5 cm lateral to the edge of the central tendon to avoid the posterolateral and anterolateral branches of the phrenic nerve




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 163.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for childhood acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
With its lack of ionising radiation, USG should be the investigation of choice/best diagnostic investigation for acute appendicitis in children. Ultrasound has a sensitivity of 85-90% and specificity of 95-100% for diagnosing appendicitis.

Computed tomography may be done in cases if the diagnosis is in doubt. CT is considered the Investigation of choice in adults, not in children. 
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 281,282

questions.text: What kind of test should be used to rule out biliary atresia in a 1-month-old baby?
questions.solution:
• Investigation of choice to rule out biliary atresia in a 1-month-old child is Hepatic scintigraphy.
  • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy with technetium-labeled iminodiacetic acid derivatives (HIDA scan) is used to differentiate biliary atresia from non­ obstructive causes of cholestasis.
  • Uptake by hepatocytes is intact, but excretion depends on patent bile ducts.
  • In biliary atresia -uptake occurs, but no excretion into intestine (even after pretreatment with phenobarbital, which stimulates bile flow).
  • High negative predictive value - if tracer passes into intestine, BA is ruled out.
  • Hence, the Investigation of choice/test to rule out BA.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 327

questions.text: Which physiological change amongst the following isn't anticipated during laparoscopic surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Increased pH
 
  • Regarding pathophysiology of pneumoperitoneum - CO2 is rapidly absorbed across the peritoneal membrane into the circulation. In the circulation, CO2 creates a respiratory acidosis by the generation of carbonic acid.
  • Body buffers, the largest reserve of which lies in bone, absorb CO2 (up to 120 L) and minimize the development of hypercarbia or respiratory acidosis during brief endoscopic procedures.
  • Once the body buffers are saturated, respiratory acidosis develops rapidly, and the respiratory system assumes the burden of keeping up with the absorption of CO2 and its release from these buffers.

*[Extra Edge]: Pneumoperitoneum

The physiologic effects of CO2 pneumoperitoneum can be divided into two areas: (a) gas-specific effects and (b) pressure specific effects.


Fig: Carbon dioxide gas insufflated into the peritoneal cavity
  • Hypercarbia also causes tachycardia and increased systemic vascular resistance, which elevates blood pressure and increases myocardial oxygen demand.
  • The most common arrhythmia created by laparoscopy is bradycardia. A rapid stretch of the peritoneal membrane often causes a vagovagal response with bradycardia and, occasionally, hypotension.
  • The increased pressure of the pneumoperitoneum is transmitted directly across the paralyzed diaphragm to the thoracic cavity, creating increased central venous pressure and increased filling pressures of the right and left sides of the heart. If the intra-abdominal pressures are kept under 20 mmHg, the cardiac output usually is well maintained.
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure decreases renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate, and urine output. These effects may be mediated by direct pressure on the kidney and the renal vein.
  • The direct effect of the pneumoperitoneum on increasing intrathoracic pressure increases peak inspiratory pressure, pressure across the chest wall, and also, the likelihood of barotrauma.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 455.

choices.text: Based on portal vein and hepatic vein only
There are three major and three minor fissures

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the basis of functional divisions of the liver ?
questions.solution:
The functional divisions of the liver are based on the portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile ducts, which divide the liver into eight segments. These segments are further grouped into four sectors. The concept of fissures (major or minor) does not accurately describe the basis of these functional divisions.





Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1205-1207

questions.text: How much platelet count is needed following a transfusion in a patient with thrombocytopenia in order to undergo an invasive procedure?
questions.solution:
The target platelet count in a patient with thrombocytopenia after transfusion undergoing an invasive procedure is 50000. 
 
  • In an otherwise healthy patient, surgery can be safely performed if platelet counts are above 50,000/mm³.
  • The risk of bleeding significantly increases when platelet counts fall below this threshold.
  • Platelet transfusions can help manage thrombocytopenia, raising the platelet count by approximately 10,000/mm³ for each unit transfused.
 
  • Thrombocytopenia is defined as a platelet count lower than normal and can result from conditions such as immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), drug-induced thrombocytopenia, rheumatological diseases (like SLE and rheumatoid arthritis), pregnancy, and chronic liver disease. If a patient presents with a low platelet count, the first step is to repeat the test and examine the peripheral blood smear.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 963, 964, 967, 968.

questions.text: What is the most frequently used and accepted form of bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  is 4. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
 
  • Most commonly performed and acceptable method of bariatric surgery among given options is Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
  • However, the better answer to this question will be sleeve gastrectomy.
  • Since it is not there in the given options, we should mark the second best answer which is roux-en-Y gastric bypass.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1181.

questions.text: What antihypertensive medication is not prescribed during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Enalapril
 
  • Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor and ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • They cause severe fetal malformations such as fetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and fetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during later half of pregnancy.
  • A recent report indicates 2.7-fold higher malformation rate in fetuses exposed to ACE inhibitors in the first trimester.
  • ACE inhibitors must be stopped when the woman conceives.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 531.

questions.text: What are the cut-off values for an oral glucose tolerance test performed after fasting and one and two hours after eating?
questions.solution:
Cut-off values in 2 hours oral glucose tolerance test for fasting and at 1 hour and 2 hours after meals are 92, 180 and 153  respectively.

questions.text: A mother has a history of her first child dying in utero from a neural tube abnormality. How much folic acid will be prescribed during preconception counselling?
questions.solution:
• Folic acid supplementation is recommended for women with seizure disorders who are taking antiepileptic medications because these medications can interfere with the absorption of folate.
  • To reduce the risk of neural tube defects in offspring, women should start taking folic acid supplements three months before becoming pregnant.
  • If a pregnancy is planned in high-risk women (previously affected child with neural tube defects),supplementation should be started with 4 mg (= 4000 microgram) of folic acid daily.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 735.

questions.text: A G6+0+0 lady with h/o recurrent missed abortions at 14–16 weeks comes to you with a missed abortion at 12 weeks. Which of the following tests is not warranted?
questions.solution:
Though VDRL is a simple test, mostly performed in initial work up of all cases of multiple abortions, in this case all abortions are by 16th week while in syphilis, usually there is an improvement in the duration of pregnancy (Kassowitz Law).
 
  • Most common cause of isolated abortion is Chromosomal aberrations (Aneuploidy). So, we need to perform fetal Karyotype for diagnosis of trisomy, monosomy etc.
  • One of the important causes of recurrent 2nd trimester abortion is Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). 
Laboratory Criteria for diagnosis of APS/APLA: 
  1. Presence of lupus anticoagulant according to guidelines of the International Society on Thrombosis and Hemostasis (OR)
  2. Medium or high serum levels of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies (OR)
  3. Anti-β2 glycoprotein-I IgG or IgM antibody

questions.text: What level of proteinuria is required to identify severe preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
300 mg

Criteria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia
  • Systolic blood pressure \(\geq\) 140 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure \(\geq\) 90 mm Hg on two occasions at least four hours apart after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient and
  • Proteinuria \(\geq\) 0.3 grams in a 24-hour urine specimen or protein (mg/dL) creatinine (mg/dL) ratio \(\geq\)0.3
  • Dipstick 1+ if a quantitative measurement is unavailable.
In patients with new-onset hypertension without proteinuria, the new onset of any of the following is diagnosis of preeclampsia:
  • Platelet count <100,000/microliter
  • Serum creatinine > 1.1 mg/dL or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease
  • Liver transaminases at least twice the normal concentrations
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Cerebral or visual symptoms

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 689.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female patient was admitted with primary amenorrhea. Her mother stated that when she was 12 years old, she first began to develop breasts.
A doctor gave her OCPs two years ago, but they had no impact. She played football and was of average height. Examination revealed minimal pubic hair (Tanner's stage 1) and well-developed breasts (Tanner's stage 5). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Most likely diagnosis in a 16-year old girl who presents with primary amenorrhea, normal sexual development, normal breasts (Tanner stage 5) but minimal pubic hair (Tanner stage I) is androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: Because the testes produce normal amounts of mullerian-inhibiting factor (MlF), also known as mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) or anti-mullerian hormone/factor (AMH/AMF), affected individuals do not have fallopian tubes, a uterus, or a proximal (upper) vagina.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3002, 3003.

questions.text: Which medication is not prescribed for PCOD in a 30-year-old woman with infertility?
questions.solution:
• Drug not given in PCOD in a 30-year-old lady with infertility is OCP as OCP itself is a contraceptive agent which inhibits ovulation.
  • Rest all the drugs above can be given in PCOD with infertility

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly prescribed for managing symptoms of PCOD (such as irregular periods, acne, and hirsutism) by regulating menstrual cycles and reducing androgen levels. However, they are generally not prescribed when a woman is seeking to conceive, as they prevent ovulation and therefore do not aid in achieving pregnancy.

In contrast:

  1. Clomiphene and

  2. Letrozole are ovulation-inducing medications used to help women with PCOD and infertility to conceive.

  3. Metformin may also be prescribed to improve insulin sensitivity, which can aid in ovulation and support fertility in women with PCOD.

 



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 316.

questions.text: Which medication is preferred for pregnancy-related hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Methyldopa
 
  • Drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy is methyldopa.
  • Methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is a prodrug that exerts its antihypertensive action via an active metabolite.
  • Methyldopa was a widely used antihypertensive in the 1960s and 1970s, especially in combination with a diuretic. However, it is rarely used now, except to treat hypertension during pregnancy wherein it has a long track record of safety, both for the mother as well as the fetus.
  • Labetolol is preferred to Methyl dopa due to the drugs association with post partum depression
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text:
A woman who had an abdominal lump was examined. After surgery, it was discovered that she had smooth-surfaced bilateral ovarian tumors.
On microscopy, they showed signet-ring-shaped mucin-secreting cells. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Krukenberg tumor

  • Signet-ring-shaped mucin-secreting cells are characteristic of Krukenberg tumor. 
  • The tumor is usually bilateral, solid with smooth surfaces and usually maintaining the shape of the ovary. The typically form rounded or reniform, firm white masses. Sometimes they are bosselated and may attain a big size. There is no tendency of adhesion (i.e. capsule remains intact).
  • The cut surfaces usually look yellow or white in color with cystic space at places due to degeneration. Cut surface has waxy consistency.
  • Histologically, the stroma is highly cellular. The mucin within epithelial cells compresses the nuclei to one pole, producing ‘signet ring’ appearance. The scattered ‘signet ring’ looking cells are characteristic of Krukenberg tumor.
  • In most patients with Krukenberg’s tumors, the prognosis is poor. Median survival being less than a year. Rarely, no primary site can be identified and the Krukenberg’s tumor may be a primary tumor.





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 464, 465.

questions.text: A woman had a vaginal hysterectomy because she had cervix cancer. Her urethral catheter was removed during surgery, and she later complained of urine incontinence. She was found to be incontinent continuously, as well as voiding normally. Through her urethra, methylene blue dye was injected into her bladder, and phenazopyridine dye was administered orally. When her pads were checked later, the topmost pad had a yellow stain, but neither the middle nor the bottom pads did. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in the bladder and was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula.



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1791.

questions.text: What other research might you suggest in galactorrhoea-amenorrhea disorders other than serum prolactin?
questions.solution:
Apart from prolactin, TSH should be advised in a patient of galactorrhea-amenorrhea syndrome. 
 
  • Basal, fasting morning PRL levels (normally <20 μg/L) should be measured to assess hypersecretion. Both false-positive and false-negative results may be encountered.
 
  • Galactorrhea and Amenorrhea are commonly associated with hyperprolactinemia caused by many conditions.
 
  • Hypothyroidism should be excluded by measuring TSH and T4 levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2909.

questions.text: Which tests can be performed safely to determine the earliest stage of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The safest and most effective test to determine the earliest stage of pregnancy is: Option 3. Serum β-hCG levels
 

  • Serum β-hCG levels: This is a reliable and early marker for detecting pregnancy. Serum β-hCG can typically detect pregnancy as early as 8–11 days post-conception, even before a missed period.
  • USG for fetal cardiac activity (Option 1): While a transvaginal ultrasound can detect an early pregnancy sac around 4–5 weeks gestation, fetal cardiac activity usually isn’t visible until around 6–7 weeks.
  • Fetal cardiac Doppler study (Option 2): This is typically not used in early pregnancy detection, as it’s meant to assess fetal cardiac function, which becomes relevant at later stages.
  • MRI pelvis (Option 4): MRI is rarely used in early pregnancy due to the lack of necessity and higher cost; it’s also generally reserved for specific clinical indications later in pregnancy.

So, serum β-hCG levels is the best and safest option for determining early pregnancy.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no: 175-177.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child appears with an umbilical and hypogastric lump in the lower abdomen. Upon examination, it is found to be mobile and cystic, and the examiner is unable to get their fingers between the mass and the pelvic bone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

Upon examination, the mass was found to be mobile and cystic, and the examiner was unable to get their fingers between the mass and the pelvic bone. This indicates pelvic origin of the mass which is most likely to be an ovarian cyst.

A 10-year-old child was seen with frothy urine, oliguria, and edema. He hasn't previously received any complaints like this. His urine was examined and revealed 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs or WBCs, and no casts. His blood creatinine level was 0.5 mg/dL, and his serum albumin level was 2.5 gm/L.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

On examination, urine is positive for 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs/WBCs and no casts, with serum albumin 2.5 glL and serum creatinine 0.5 mg/ dL, the most likely diagnosis is minimal change disease.
  • Main features of Nephrotic syndrome- Massive proteinuria, Hypoalbuminemia, Edema and Hyperlipidemia.
  • Most common cause of Nephrotic syndrome in children- Minimal Change Disease.

questions.text: Which is the initial fluid of choice for diarrhoea in an infant?
questions.solution:
The cornerstone of acute diarrhoea management is rehydration. The initial fluid of choice for diarrhea in an infant is Oral Rehydration Solution. It is specifically formulated to treat dehydration by replacing lost fluids and electrolytes. ORS contains the optimal ratio of sodium and glucose to facilitate sodium–glucose co-transport in the intestinal mucosa, which enhances water absorption.



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics 21 St Page No 2028

questions.text:
A 7-month-old baby who had previously vomited and struggled to grow was examined. With the help of intravenous glucose, the patient recovered and emerged from a coma in less than 24 hours. He returned a month later with the same complaints. Following an examination, he is found to have elevated blood ammonia and no ketones.
He also exhibits high urine levels of uracil, alanine, and glutamine. What enzyme deficiency does this patient most probably have?
questions.solution:
• Ornithine transcarbamoylase.
  • The recurrent symptoms with raised ammonia levels point towards the diagnosis of a Urea cycle defect
  • The most common urea cycle defect is due to deficiency of the enzyme Ornithine transcarbamoylase.
  • OTC deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder, primarily affecting males, though females can be affected in varying degrees due to lyonization (random X-inactivation).
  • Pathophysiology: The deficiency of the OTC enzyme impairs the conversion of carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine into citrulline, leading to the accumulation of ammonia in the blood.
  • Hyperammonemia: Accumulation of ammonia can lead to symptoms such as:
    • Vomiting
    • Lethargy
    • Seizures
    • Coma
    • Neurological impairment
  • Symptoms in newborns: Often present within the first few days of life with severe symptoms.
  • Late-onset: Some individuals may have a later onset of symptoms, often triggered by illness, stress, or high protein intake.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537257/

questions.text:
Hepatojejunal anastomosis was used in surgery for biliary stricture in a child. After two weeks, the postoperative bilirubin level dropped from 12 mg/dL to 6 mg/dL.
What could be the reason for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Delta bilirubin
 
  • Delta Bilirubin: Part of the direct-reacting Bilirubin fraction includes conjugated bilirubin that is covalently linked to albumin. This albumin-linked bilirubin fraction (delta fraction, or biliprotein) represents an important fraction of total serum bilirubin in patients with cholestasis and hepatobiliary disorders.
  • By virtue of its tight binding to albumin, the clearance rate of albumin-bound bilirubin from serum approximates the half-life of albumin, 12-14 days, rather than the short half-life of bilirubin, about 4 hours.
  • Significance of delta bilirubin in patients with obstructive jaundice: It has been observed that there is an inverse correlation between delta-bilirubin and total bilirubin concentration.
  • In patients with good drainage, the percentage of delta-bilirubin increase within 7 days after biliary drainage procedure, but it did not reach 60% by 28 days in the patients with poor drainage.
  • The increase in the percentage of serum delta-bilirubin indicates effectiveness of biliary drainage.

Reference: Kozaki N, Shimizu S, Higashijima H, Kuroki S, Yamashita H, Yamaguchi K, Chijiiwa K, Tanaka M. Significance of serum delta-bilirubin in patients with obstructive jaundice. J Surg Res. 1998 Sep;79(1):61-5. doi: 10.1006/jsre.1998.5357. PMID: 9735241.

questions.text: A young patient is diagnosed with an irreparable rotator cuff tear. What will be the preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
• Treatment of choice for irreparable tear of the rotator cuff in a young patient is tendon transfer.
  • Hemiarthroplasty can provide good long-term results in rotator cuff-deficient patients with glenohumeral arthritis.
  • Total shoulder replacement  and reverse shoulder replacement  are typically reserved for cases where there is severe arthritis or other joint damage in addition to the rotator cuff tear.
  • Acromioplasty  is a surgical procedure to remove a small portion of the acromion bone in the shoulder to relieve pressure on the rotator cuff tendons, but it is not typically used for irreparable rotator cuff tears.
