questions.text: What is the most typical method of retinoblastoma spread?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Optic nerve invasion
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a common cancerous tumour that develops in one or both eyes from the neurosensory retina.
  • Retinoblastoma (RB) gene has been discovered as 14 band on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q 14) and is a 'cancer suppressor' or 'antioncogenic' gene. Retinoblastoma is caused by the deletion or inactivation of the RB gene by two mutations (Knudson's two-hit hypothesis).
  • The most frequent presenting symptom is leukocoria, or a yellowish-white pupillary reflex (cat's eye appearance in amaurosis).
  • Common spread involves direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 349, 350.

questions.text: What causes a "cherry red spot" to appear after trauma in children?
questions.solution:
Cherry red spots after trauma are seen in children due to Berlin’s edema (Commotio retinae).
 
  • This is a common result of a blow on the eye.
  • A milky white cloudiness due to edema appears over a considerable area at the posterior pole with a cherry red spot in the foveal region, which may sometimes disappear after a few days when vision is usually restored.




Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 500.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 448, 449.

questions.text: A painful unilateral vision loss is seen in a patient. He provides a timeline of afterimage persistence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Ocular ischemic syndrome
 
  • Decrease in visual acuity in OIS may be severe, with acute or subacute presentation
  • Visual fields on presentation can vary greatly from normal, to a central scotoma, nasal defects, centrocecal defects, and the presence only of a central or temporal island.
  • A history of transient visual loss is present in approximately 10–15% of patients with OIS. This is most frequently caused by transient embolization of the CRA or its branches, but vasospasm may also play a role. In these cases, a dark or black shade spreads across the visual field that lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Less commonly, severe carotid artery disease causes transient visual loss as a result of choroidal hypoperfusion. Conditions that either increase retinal metabolic demands or decrease perfusion pressure can precipitate transient visual loss and reflect the inability of a borderline ocular circulation to maintain stable the ocular blood flow. This has been reported following exposure to bright light, postural change, or after eating a meal. Visual loss resulting from hypoperfusion of the choroid often lasts several minutes to hours and may be associated with positive visual phenomena.

Pain:
  • Pain may be present in up to 40% of the eyes with OIS. Pain may be the result of increased IOP or may be ischemic in origin. Ischemic pain begins gradually over hours to days and is described as a dull, constant ache in the affected eye, over the orbit, upper face, and temple, and may worsen when the patient is upright. Lying down relieves or lessens pain.
  • The description "ocular angina" may be used to describe this discomfort. Ischemic pain may be confused with that from secondary glaucoma, but pain in eyes with OIS would not be explained by a slight IOP elevation. Pain from both increased IOP and ischemia may be present in the same patient. In older patients, giant cell arteritis should be excluded.

Hallucinatory Palinopsia:
  • Refers to a pathological group of visual symptoms in which there is an abnormal persistence or recurrence of an image in time.
  • Palinopsia is associated with a dysfunction of visual memory. It can be caused by posterior cortical lesions or seizures . Examples of lesions that may cause hallucinatory palinopsia are neoplasms, infarctions, hemorrhages, arteriovenous malformations, aneurysm, abscesses, and tuberculomas. The seizures that cause palinopsia are associated with metabolic imbalances, such as hyperglycemia, carnitine deficiency, ion channel disturbances, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
  • Illusory palinopsia is associated with alterations in visual perception of a real external stimulus affected by immediate environmental factors. Illusory palinopsia can be caused by changes in neurotransmitter receptors associated with migraines hallucinogen persisting perception disorder (HPPD) , trauma to the head, or drugs or other medications. Medications that have been reported to cause illusory palinopsia include trazodone , nefazodone, mirtazapine , topiramate, clomiphene, oral contraceptives, and risperidone. Palinopsia may also be idiopathic.





Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 553.

Cherry red spots and Hollenhorst plaque are seen in both CRAO and BRAO. But the incidence of CRAO is more common than BRAO.
A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because the nerve fiber layer is thin.
Three main types of retinal emboli have been identified in CRAO:
• Cholesterol (Hollenhorst plaque).
• Platelet-fibrin.
• Calcific.

questions.text: Which is the universal marker of limbal epithelial stem cells?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. ABCG2
 
  • ABCG2 is a member of the ATP binding cassette (ABC) transporters, localizes predominantly to the plasma membrane and has been proposed as a universal and conserved marker for stem cells from a wide variety of tissues.
 
  • Currently, of the most widely accepted combination of markers for LSCs (ΔNp63α, C/EBPσ, Bmi1, ABCG2, and Notch-1) only ABCG2 and Notch-1 are expressed on the cell surface.



Reference: Joe, Aaron W, and Sonia N Yeung. “Concise review: identifying limbal stem cells: classical concepts and new challenges.” Stem cells translational medicine vol. 3,3 (2014): 318-22. doi:10.5966/sctm.2013-0137

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used to diagnose corneal granular dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Masson’s trichrome
  • Trichrome Masson is used in staining for Granular dystrophy, Lattice dystrophy, Avellino  dystrophy.
  • Masson’s trichrome staining shows accumulation of hyaline material in the corneal stroma and beneath the epithelium. 
  • PAS(Periodic acid Schiff) for lattice dystrophy, Macular dystrophy, Avellino dystrophy.
  • Alcian blue for Macular dystrophy
  • Congo red (under polarization) Lattice dystrophy ,Avellino dystrophy



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 262, 263.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot lead to a right trochlear nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Trochlear nerve palsy typically manifests with specific symptoms related to the affected eye’s movement and alignment, such as diplopia on upward gaze and adduction, and compensatory right head tilt to alleviate symptoms. Hyperopia (farsightedness) does not directly cause a trochlear nerve palsy; instead, it affects visual acuity due to the way light focuses on the retina, and it is not associated with the specific ocular motor deficits characteristic of a trochlear nerve palsy.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 774,775

questions.text: What one of the following is not an indication of evisceration?
questions.solution:
Malignancy is NOT an indication of Evisceration.

Indications of evisceration:
  • Endophthalmitis, Panophthalmitis
  • Expulsive Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Penetrating ocular trauma
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma
  • Blind, painful eye

Contraindications: 
  • Known or suspected intraocular malignancy
  • Phthisis bulbi and microphthalmia (relative)
 
  • Evisceration may be more difficult in cases of phthisis bulbi or microphthalmos due to a lack of sufficient scleral shell volume to adequately encase the implant. While enucleation is generally the preferred surgical choice in these patients.
 
  • Malignancy is an absolute contraindication to evisceration. An enucleation should be performed whenever managing an eye suspected or known to harbor an intraocular malignancy.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 178,179.

questions.text: To evaluate the function of _____, a multifocal ERG is helpful.
questions.solution:
ERG is useful to assess the function of macular cones.

The multifocal (mf)–ERG represents a cone-generated response of localized retinal function in the central macula, which is useful in establishing the presence of macular dysfunction.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 462.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in higher concentrations in the vitreous humour than in the blood?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Ascorbate
 
  • As compared to human aqueous humor, vitreous humor has high concentration of ascorbate.
 
  • Vitreous vitamin C (Ascorbate) is physiologically high in the non-diabetic eye whereas it is severely impaired in the diabetic eye. The mean concentration of ascorbate in the vitreous humor is approximately 2 mM, whereas blood levels are only 50–60 μM, which is a 33- to 40-fold difference.



Reference: Park, Sung Wook et al. “Association of vitreous vitamin C depletion with diabetic macular ischemia in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.” PloS one vol. 14,6 e0218433. 19 Jun. 2019, doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0218433

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about direct ophthalmoscopy?
questions.solution:
Magnification is direct ophthalmoscopy is 15 times. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, magnification is 4-5 times.

Other features of Direct Ophthalmoscopy:
  • Battery operated, hand-held, Self-illuminated device 
  • Done in sitting posture
  • Mainly used to see central retina (posterior pole of retina upto the equator)
  • 2DD of central retina visible
  • Image formed is virtual, erect and magnified
  • About 15X magnification 


Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.

questions.text: Which of the following is the purpose of the Kashima operation?
questions.solution:
Kashima's operation or transverse cordotomy is used for vocal cord palsy. 

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 407

questions.text: What method is the most effective for evaluating eustachian tube function?
questions.solution:
Eustachian tube function is assessed by both tympanometry and Politzer test. However, the better answer will be tympanometry. 


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 63

questions.text: What is included in topical therapy for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis?
questions.solution:
Topical treatment for recurrent respiratory papillomatosis includes cidofovir.
Reference : https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/302648-medication

questions.text: Which vessel is primarily responsible for bleeding caused by juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
The main vessel involved in bleeding from Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is Internal maxillary artery.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 279

questions.text: A child was brought in with lesions over the elbows and penis shaft that were similar to those in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Grouped pin/read lesions on elbow, abdomen, penis and dorsum of hand in a child as shown in the picture is highly suggestive of lichen nitidus.
  • Lichen nitidus appears as small, shiny, flat-topped bumps that are skin-colored, yellow, red-brown, or violet. They can be 1–3 mm in diameter and are often round or polygonal in shape.
  • It  can be localized or generalized, and  can cluster together to form plaques.
 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man from Bihar arrives with papules  which are hypopigmented and normal sensation over his face and the back of his neck.
A prolonged fever episode in childhood was documented while taking  history. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is based on:
  • History of kala-azar in the past (1-5 years ago) or living in endemic area.
  • Presence of "juicy'' erythematous nodules on the central part of the face.
  • Hypopigmented macules on the central part of the trunk.
  • No nerve involvement
  • PKDL can appear weeks, months, or even years after successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, often occurring in endemic regions.
  • Diagnosis is typically made based on clinical examination and history of previous leishmaniasis infection, with possible confirmation through skin biopsies or serological test

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

questions.text: A patient arrived with a 7-day history of bullae covering more than 30% of the body's surface area as well as erosions of the lips and other mucosae. What is the likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
• The above picture shows a forearm with extensive reddish bullae involving >30% body surface area and the description is typical of the spectrum of Steven-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a rare, life-threatening skin condition that is usually caused by a reaction to drugs.
  • SJS/TEN is a rare, but potentially life-threatening, hypersensitivity reaction to certain medications and less commonly infections more commonly viral infections 
  • It is characterized by the formation of painful bullae, erosions, and ulcerations of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • The condition typically presents within the first few weeks of starting a new medication, although it can occur at any time during treatment. Many medications have been associated with SJS, including antibiotics (e.g., sulfonamides), anticonvulsants (e.g., phenytoin), and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (e.g., ibuprofen).
  • The exact mechanism of SJS is not fully understood, but it is thought to be a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which involves activation of T-cells and subsequent release of cytokines.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: The following lesions are present across the body, primarily on the trunk, in a 7-month-old  pregnant woman. Which of these medications is most suitable for the treatment?
questions.solution:
• The image given is of Pustular Psoriasis of Pregnancy.
  • Usually seen in third trimester
  • Recur in subsequent pregnancy
  • Presents with scaling on trunk/abdomen/legs.
  • DOC- Oral steroids ( only type of psoriasis where oral steroids are used)


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.28

questions.text:
As seen in the image, a 25-year-old woman arrived with erythematous papules on her face. Excessive perspiration, exposure to the sun,
and emotional distress all made the lesions worse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis of this 25-year-old girl with erythematous papules on the face as seen in the picture with exacerbated lesions on excessive sweating, sun exposure and emotional disturbance is acne rosacea.
  • Acne rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the face, particularly the cheeks, nose, chin, and forehead.
  • It is characterized by redness, flushing, and the appearance of papules and pustules. The condition is often worsened by triggers such as sun exposure, emotional stress, and alcohol consumption.
  • Photodermatitis is a skin reaction that occurs after exposure to sunlight and is characterized by redness, itching, and blisters, but it does not usually present with papules.
  • SLE is close differential , but it has other systemic features with sparing of Nasolabial folds.
  • Below is an image of Lupus Rash vs  Rosacea. Note the sparing of the nasolabial folds.




Reference- Illustrated Synopsis of Dermatology and Sexually Transmitted Diseases, Neena Khanna, 4th edition, page number 121, 122.

questions.text: A woman complained of a bluish lesion across the left side of the forehead and left eye when she arrived. An irregular bluish lesion is detected in the left superior conjunctiva and forehead. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given picture shows an irregular bluish lesion in the left superior maxillary and ophthalmic region of trigeminal nerve in a female patient. The most probable diagnosis is Nevus of Ota.
  • It is caused by the accumulation of melanocytes in the area and is more commonly seen in women of Asian descent. The lesion is usually present at birth or appears in early childhood, but can also develop later in life.
  • Nevus of Ito is a similar condition, but the pigmentation is located on the shoulder and upper arm.
  • Becker's nevus is a hairy patch of skin that appears on the shoulder or upper chest.
  •  Mongolian spot is a common birthmark that appears as a blue-gray patch on the lower back or buttocks.



Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/nevus-of-ota

questions.text:
A man with leprosy arrived with the shin lesion shown in the image below.
Which spectrum of Leprosy does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
• Inverted saucer-shaped lesions are characteristic features of borderline Borderline (BB) leprosy.



 




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10

questions.text: A woman arrived with unilateral leukotrichia and white skin lesions, as shown in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A lady came with unilateral white skin lesions with leukotrichia as shown in the picture. Most likely diagnosis is segmental vitiligo.
  • Segmental Vitiligo:Occurs along a nerve segment
  • Common on face along the branches of trigeminal nerve
  • Stable course, i.e., lesions increase initially (6-12 months) and then remain static.
  • Leukotrichia on the depigmented areas as well as away from vitiliginous areas frequently seen. Margins are feathery.
  • Piebaldism, is a genetic condition that is present from birth and results in a white forelock of hair and depigmented patches on the skin, but it usually affects both sides of the body.
  • Focal vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that affects only a few small areas of the body
  • Waardenburg syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects hearing, pigmentation, and eye color.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: As shown in the picture, a patient presented with itchy, tight blisters on both healthy skin and over urticarial plaques. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis in this patient with tense blisters on normal-looking skin-associated urticaria/ plaques as seen in the figure points towards a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid.
  • The blisters can occur on healthy skin or over urticarial plaques, which are raised, itchy patches of skin. The blisters are typically itchy and can be painful.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris typically affects the mucous membranes rather than the skin.
  • Linear IgA disease typically affects the skin around the mouth, eyes, and genitals.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis causes itchy, blistering rashes, but it is typically associated with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease.



PV- Pemphigus vulgaris
PF- Pemphigus foliaceus 
EBA-Epidermolysis bullosa Acquisita
Pveg- Pemphigus Vegetans 







Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: A vesicle was discovered on the shin of a patient. The Tzanck smear microscopy revealed enormous cells. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Vesicles on shin and giant cells(enormous cells) on Tzanck smear suggest the diagnosis of Herpes Zoster.


Herpes zoster, commonly known as shingles, is a reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the same virus that causes chickenpox.

Clinical Diagnosis: Primarily based on the characteristic appearance of the rash and associated symptoms.
Laboratory Tests: PCR testing of vesicular fluid can confirm the diagnosis if necessary, but it’s usually not required for typical cases.

Treatment-Antiviral Medications: Acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir can reduce the severity and duration of the illness if started within 72 hours of rash onset.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 451.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations is appropriate for daycare surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Remifentanil, midazolam, propofol
 
  • Drug combination, which can be used for day care surgery are remifentanil, midazolam and propofol. 
  • Remifentanil is a short-acting opioid analgesic that provides rapid pain relief and is easy to titrate.
  • Midazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine that provides sedation and amnesia.
  • Thiopentone sodium (Propofol) is a short-acting anesthetic agent that provides rapid induction and recovery, making it an ideal choice for daycare surgery.
  • These drugs have a short duration of action and are metabolized quickly, allowing for a smooth and rapid recovery from anesthesia.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 641, 647, 657, 658, 713.

questions.text: Which anaesthetic can cause pain when it is injected into a vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Propofol

Propofol causes pain on IV administration. Propofol is oil-based preparation containing soybean oil, egg lecithin and glycerol.
As it contains oil so injection is painful and should be preceded or mixed with lignocaine. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 410.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of coronary artery disease arrives with a low blood pressure and a pulse rate of 48/min. On echo, the patient's cardiac contractility has diminished.
Which of these anaesthetic substances should not be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dexmedetomidine
 
  • This patient is having bradycardia, hypotension and reduced cardiac output. Dexmedetomidine is contraindicated in hypovolemia, hypotension, heart block and congestive heart failure.
  • Dexmedetomidine is a centrally active selective alpha-2 agonist with strong sedative properties

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 412.

questions.text: Can a muscle relaxant be used in a patient with a serum bilirubin level of 6.0 and a creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atracurium
 
  • Muscle relaxant that can be used in a patient with high serum bilirubin of 6.0 and serum creatinine of 4.5 mg1dL is Atracurium because of unique metabolism independent of hepatic and renal functions, known as Hoffman elimination.
  •  Atracurium is the DOC in Hepatic and Renal Failure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 380.

questions.text: What is the best noninvasive test to determine the myocardium's viability?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. PET-CT
 
  • For the evaluation of myocardial viability in patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy, myocardial perfusion imaging (with SPECT or PET) is usually combined with metabolic imaging (i.e., fluorodeoxyglucose [FDG] PET).
  • In hospital settings lacking access to PET scanning, thallium-201 SPECT imaging is an excellent alternative.
  • FDG PET is also used in the evaluation of myocardial and vascular inflammation and in patients with suspected infective endocarditis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1834, 1835.

questions.text: The use of an implantable cardioverter is being used to treat a patient with a history of tachyarrhythmias. What is the most effective way to learn the location and integrity of the ICD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Plain Radiograph

A plain radiograph/X-Ray is the modality of choice to determine the location of implantable cardioverter defibrillator. 
  • CXR allows visualization of ICD leads and the generator with its position relative to the heart. It can also detect if there are any complications such as Lead dislodgement or migration.
  • CT scan or Fluoroscopy is used if detained analysis of the pacemaker is required, however CXR is the most effective way and the first line investigation to locate an ICD.
  • MRI is contraindicated in this case. 
Hence, Best method to know the position and integrity of ICD is plain radiograph.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1914.

questions.text: The use of an implantable cardioverter is being used to treat a patient with a history of tachyarrhythmias. What is the most effective way to learn the location of ICD?
questions.solution:
Chest X ray is the most effective and best way to locate an ICD.
  • CXR allows visualization of ICD leads and the generator with its position relative to the heart. It can also detect if there are any complications such as Lead dislodgement or migration.
  • CT scan or Fluoroscopy is used if detained analysis of the pacemaker is required, however CXR is the most effective way and the first line investigation to locate an ICD.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1914.

questions.text: Which of these does not fall under the category of catatonia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Akathisia
 
  • Akathisia is not a part of catatonia.
  • Akathisia is defined as an inability to remain still. It is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that is associated with psychomotor restlessness. The individual with akathisia will generally experience an intense sensation of unease or an inner restlessness that usually involves the lower extremities. 
  • It is also a known extrapyramidal side effect of anti-dopaminergic drugs like Anti-psychotics (Haloperidol/Fluphenazine) 
  • It typically tends to develop 5-50 days post antipsychotic initiation and management includes using drugs like Propranolol/Benzodiazepines. 
Other options- 
  • Ambivalence- having contradictory feelings
  • Ambitendency- acting opposite ways
  • Akinesia- No movement

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 343-345, 926.

questions.text: Where do we see feelings of uneasiness and an excessive sense of responsibility?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Obsessive-Compulsive disorder
 
  • Pathological doubts (feelings of uncertainty) and an excessive sense of responsibility are both symptoms/types of OCD
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a disorder in which people have recurring, unwanted thoughts, ideas, or sensations (obsessions) that give them feelings of uneasiness. To get rid of the thoughts, they feel driven to do something repetitively (compulsions).
  • Responsibility OCD is a subtype of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in which you experience an intense and irrational belief that you're responsible for preventing harm or negative events, even when they're beyond your control.
Other options- 
  • Phobia is unnecessary fear of something
  • Generalized Anxiety Disorder has free floating anxiety 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 422.

questions.text: A smoker is concerned about smoking's negative effects. However, he continues to smoke since he believes he smokes less than other people and has a healthy diet. What is this process of thought known as?
questions.solution:
• Many smokers continue to support "self-exempting beliefs," also known as risk-minimizing beliefs or risk denial of smoking hazards, in spite of comprehensive tobacco control measures.
  • These ideas are used to justify or rationalize continuing to smoke despite the well-known adverse effects of tobacco use.
  • In accordance with cognitive dissonance theory, these ideas lessen the tension that results when one's knowledge of behavior is at odds with the actual behavior.


Reference: How do self-exempt beliefs affect intentions to quit smoking? An exploration of the mediating role of threat appraisal and coping appraisal Frontiers in Psychology Vol 14, 2023, DOI=10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1260561, URL=https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/psychology/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1260561

questions.text: Which cluster would a person with a shy, neurotic, or avoidant personality fall under?
questions.solution:
A person with a shy, anxious-avoidant personality comes under cluster C.


 
  • People with Avoidant Personality Disorder are often shy, sensitive to criticism, and avoid social situations due to fear of rejection or humiliation. They may also have low self-esteem and feelings of inadequacy.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 746-750.

questions.text: A man arrives with a background of strange blinking and groaning. He asserts that he is powerless over his symptoms, which have been occurring more frequently lately. His social life has started to suffer as a result. Which of the following drugs should he be given?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario suggests motor and vocal tics associated with Tourette's disorder.
  • Antipsychotics (haloperidol, risperidone) are used in this condition.
  • Risperidone is an antipsychotic medication that has been found to be effective in reducing the severity and frequency of tics in individuals with Tourette's syndrome.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1197-1199.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient with agitation and violent behaviour was being treated with haloperidol. He became rigid after that and couldn't even move his eyes. Which medication should be included in his intravenous therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Promethazine
 
  • Rigidity and inability to move eyes after haloperidol use in a patient of Schizophrenia is highly suggestive of Acute muscular dystonia.
  • Treatment with IM anticholinergic (benztropine) or IV/IM antihistaminic (diphenhydramine, Promethazine hydrochloride) almost always relieves the symptoms
  • Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine with anticholinergic and sedative properties. It is commonly used to treat nausea, vomiting, and motion sickness, but it can also be used to manage acute dystonia caused by antipsychotic medications.
  • Promethazine works by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain, which helps to alleviate the muscle spasms and rigidity associated with acute dystonia.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 782.

questions.text: What is a key sign of alcohol withdrawal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Key symptom in alcohol withdrawal syndrome is tremors.
Withdrawal Syndromes
Substance Features
Alcohol Hangover 
Hallucinations (usually auditory) and illusions
insomnia
Tremors/Seizures (Alcoholic seizures/Rum fits): Classic sign
Delirium tremens:
Occurs within 5 days of complete or significant abstinence from heavy alcohol drinking
Recovery occurs within 7 days
Characteristic features are clouding of consciousness, disorientation, hallucinations (mostly visual and auditory, illusions, autonomic disturbance and insomnia.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 630, 631.

questions.text: A woman who frequently spends a lot of time hand-washing visits the psychiatrist. Although she is upset about it, she claims that she cannot quit practicing because she invests so much time in it. Her social life has also started to suffer as a result of this. What kind of care would be most effective for her?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: EXPOSURE AND RESPONSE PREVENTION
     
  • The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called OCD – Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.
  • Management of OCD: DOC – SSRI; Antipsychotic drugs like Clomipramine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole can be given in SSRI Resistant cases. Psychotherapy of choice- CBT
  •  Exposure and response prevention should commonly be included in the cognitive behavorial therapy in OCD. Thus Exposure and Response prevention is a more specific answer than CBT. 
Some important points to remember among different psychotherapies which are frequently asked in exams:-

•            PTSD --- EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing); however the most effective therapy is CBT.
•            OCD ---- ERP (Exposure Response Prevention) included in CBT.
•            Phobia—Systemic Desensitisation – (It includes 3 steps: - Desensitisation of stimulus, Relaxation training, graded exposure)
•            Substance Use Disorder – Motivational Interviewing]

{Regarding MCQ frequently asked PTSD – EMDR (4 letters); OCD – CBT, ERP (3 letters)} --- Trick to remember it fast.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 425.
